channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Roadside Bomb Kills at Least 12 Afghans on Their Way Home
item.description: The blast occurred in the Marja district of Helmand Province, a Taliban stronghold, killing at least 12 members of a family and wounding eight.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Assailants Target Police in Burundi
item.description: Eleven police officers were wounded overnight when gunmen hurled grenades and attacked police stations across Bujumbura, Burundi’s capital.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Al Jazeera Journalist Detained in Germany
item.description: Responding to an Egyptian arrest warrant, the authorities detained Ahmed Mansour at Berlin’s Tegel airport.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Car Bombing in Yemen’s Capital Kills at Least 2
item.description: The attack on a mosque wounded at least six people, and the Islamic State’s Yemeni affiliate claimed responsibility.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Cables Released by WikiLeaks Reveal Saudis’ Checkbook Diplomacy
item.description: The revelations appear in a trove of documents said to have come from inside the Saudi Ministry of Foreign Affairs and released by the antiprivacy group WikiLeaks.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Saudi leaders, whose portraits are displayed at the stock exchange in Riyadh, have not confirmed the leak’s authenticity.

item.title: Attack Gave Chinese Hackers Privileged Access to U.S. Systems
item.description: Undetected for nearly a year, Chinese intruders executed a sophisticated hack that gave them “administrator privileges” in government networks. Their ultimate target: information on anyone seeking a security clearance.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER, NICOLE PERLROTH and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: Katherine Archuleta, director of the Office of Personnel Management, in Congress on Tuesday.

item.title: Suit Has South Korea Looking Anew at Its Hard Line on Prostitution
item.description: The case follows a landmark decision that decriminalized adultery, and reflects continuing changes in the nation’s social attitudes toward sex.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kim Jeong-mi, above, in the Cheongryangri red-light district in Seoul, filed a suit against a law that calls on the state to root out prostitution.

item.title: Opinion: The Chinese Want Their Art Back
item.description: The government, state-run companies, private collectors and even some criminals are all trying to return antiquities to China.
item.dc:creator: KARL E. MEYER

item.title: 13 Arrested in China After Clashes With Police
item.description: The police in a southern Chinese township arrested 13 people who illegally detained officials and police officers and stormed a police station and a government building in a dispute over a young woman’s death.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Gaza Welcomes Break From Strife and Reopening of Border With Egypt
item.description: First, Egypt opened its border crossing, suggesting a thaw in relations between the Egyptian government and Hamas, and then news emerged that Hamas had begun quiet negotiations with Israel to extend a truce.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinian workers unloaded pallets of cement transported from Egypt through the Rafah border crossing into southern Gaza.

item.title: Marajó Island Journal: To Soften Image, Brazilian Police Ride In Atop Horned Beasts
item.description: “Being the guy on the buffalo makes me more approachable, making my job a little bit easier,” is how one officer in Marajó, Brazil, explained it.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Marizilda Cruppe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military police officers patrolled on water buffaloes in Soure, a town of about 23,000 people on Marajó Island, as they have done since the 1990s.

item.title: For Faithful, Social Justice Goals Demand Action on Environment
item.description: Many faith traditions are awakening to the burden that climate change is placing on poor people, and finding justification for caring for the environment in their scripture.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:credit: Kaleb Nyquist/Young Evangelicals for Climate Action
item.media:description: Young Evangelicals for Climate Action held a prayer circle in September.

item.title: Toxic Liquor in India Kills at Least 84
item.description: The dead lived in a Mumbai-area slum, and the toll was expected to rise. More than 30 people were hospitalized, many in serious condition, the police said.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Relatives mourned at the funeral of a man in Mumbai who drank the tainted liquor.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Pope Francis’ Climate Error
item.description: To control emissions, a carbon market is best.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH HEATH

item.title: Dominican Deadline Passes Without Mass Expulsion of Haitian Migrants
item.description: The expected mass deportation of Haitian immigrants in the Dominican Republic failed to materialize in the two days after the government’s deadline for them to normalize their status.
item.dc:creator: SANDRA E. GARCIA and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Milene Monime, 16, in a classroom in Haiti on Thursday, a day after being deported from the Dominican Republic. Her 2-month-old son slept with another child.

item.title: Genome Studies Show How Ebola Spread Initially
item.description: Scientists have developed a fuller picture of how the virus spread and evolved by tracking mutations in its genome.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Ex-Governor Charged
item.description: The former governor of the northeast Mexican border state of Tamaulipas has been indicted on money-laundering charges in South Texas, prosecutors said Friday.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Election Bill Advances
item.description: Lawmakers in the lower house of Parliament gave tentative approval on Friday to a bill that would move up next year’s parliamentary elections by three months.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: France: Mideast Peace on Agenda
item.description: The French foreign minister will travel to the Middle East for meetings that the government asserts will be an effort to restart peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Unicef Fears Surge in Child Trafficking After Nepal Quakes
item.description: Trafficking in Nepalese children was a problem before two earthquakes struck in April, but Unicef and the government fear the ensuing chaos may make a problem even worse.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
